column4: hello; im working on installing ubuntu on a lenovo r61i, trying to dual boot it with vista
there's a lenovo recovery partition, the vista partition, and the new ext3 and swap partitions that ubuntu is creating. will a bootloader mess up my ability to use the recovery partition?

i preserved the recovery partition on this hp laptop, it even shows up in grub, presumably I could turn this back into a windows laptop, but I've never tried that so I have no idea if it would work or not, I only kept it just in case I ever sell this thing on ebay when I'm done with it
did you install the bootloader from the ubuntu install though?
because i fear that may prevent usage of the recovery software
and if i don't install the bootloader, how will i load up ubuntu on boot?

I did a full install of Ubuntu as soon as the laptop arrived by fedex, never even booted it into windows, during the install process I chose manual during the partitioning portion, and made sure to NOT delete or format the recovery partition, not sure if that answers your question but thats how I did it, I don't know if the recovery partition works or not, I will only try it when the computer is no longer useful to me
ok, thanks a lot. i'm gonna give it a try without the bootloader; worst case, i can set up the boot cmd under windows
what brand of computer is that?
lenovo r61i, i think you mentioned you had similar
I have similar restore setup
I dont know how lenevo does things but on this hp for $20 i can buy a set of restore cd's
i hear that if i call them up i can get a set, but i've not tried yet
if the ability to restore windows when its inevitability occurs is important to you, i'd not trust the restore partition to survive even if I weren't trying to dual boot another os
yeah, its not a great option
you can choose where to install grub, it can go in mbr or anywhere you send it, any partition on a hdd
you mean during the ubuntu install sequence?
if so, i may just try reinstalling ubuntu
during ubuntu install, after the partitioning bit, theres a button that says "advanced" on it, if you click that you can see a list of available places to install grub to
ok, thanks a lot.
np gl
